# 1. Overview

The Ising Model is a mathematical model used to describe the [[ferromagnetism]] of matter. It consists of a lattice of [[Dipole|magnetic moments]] or [[spin]] $S_i$ that can only take on the values of $+1$ or $-1$, representing spin up or spin down, respectively. The lattice is subject to specific interaction parameters $J$ that cause adjacent spins to influence each other. 

Although the model is quite a simplification of physical reality, it can still undergo phase transitions, and a *two-dimensional* square lattice Ising model is the simplest known physical system that can undergo a phase transition.

---

# 2. Definition

## 2.1. Hamiltonian

The [[Hamiltonian]] of the system is defined by the *interaction parameters* $J_{ij}$ and an *external magnetic field*. 

$$
\ham = -\sum_{\ev{ij}}J_{ij} S_i S_j -
\sum_j H_j S_j 
$$

$\ev{ij}$ denotes that the node $i$ and node $j$ are adjacent. Hence, the first term of [[Hamiltonian]] is the summation of energy from *spin-spin interactions* without overlap. The second term which is the energy induced by external field, called [[Zeeman Effect]].

---

>[!note]
> If $J > 0$ , the interaction tends to align spins, the whole system represents [[ferromagnetism]]. Otherwise, [[diamagnetism]].

而第二项则是*磁场和自旋交互作用的能量*。$\mu$ 是晶格点*磁矩*的值，值得注意的是，电子的磁矩和他的自旋方向相反，所以哈密顿量的第二项应该要是正号比较合理，但在习惯上，还是会令第二项为负号.

---

## 2.2. hypercubic lattice

对于Ising模型，[[spin]]的空间排布受到相互作用参数 $J_{ij}$，以及外部磁场 $h_j$ 的影响，进而决定系统的热力学量。[^1]

对于均匀磁场，我们考虑自旋在[[hypercubic lattice]]上面的空间排布

令晶格常数（lattice constant）为 $a$，超晶体一边长为 $L$，格点数为 $N$. 

则对 $d$ 维[[hypercubic lattice]]有

$$V = L^d = Na^d$$

对于任一格点，其最近邻格点数，即配位数 $z$（coordination number）满足

$$z = 2d$$

在热力学极限下，bond的数目

$$
N_{\text{bond}} = Nz/2 = Nd$$



## 2.3. Thermodynamic variables

### 2.3.1. Magnetization $M$

In Ising model, the definition of [[magnetization]] is
$$
M = \sum_{i=1}^N \ev{S_i}
$$
which means that the magnetization is the sum of the [[Partition Function#^7016be|ensemble averages]] of the spins. In addition, the magnetization conjugates with the magnetic field
$$
M = -\pdv{F}{H} = \frac{1}{\beta} \pdv{H} \ln Z
$$

The magnetization corresponding to single spin is
$$
m = \frac{M}{N} = -\pdv{f}{H} = \frac{1}{N\beta} \pdv{H} \ln Z
$$

### 2.3.2. Magnetic Susceptibility $\chi$

The [[magnetic susceptibility]] $\chi$ is defined as the rate of change of magnetization during the external magnetic field changing
$$
\chi \equiv \pdv{m}{H} = -\pdv[2]{f}{H}
$$

By the way, by the definition of the partition function, we substitute the magnetization in configuration $\qty{S_i}$ into the hamiltonian as its Zeeman term, that is, the partition function can be written as
$$
Z = \sum_{\qty{S_i}} \exp \qty[
	-\beta \qty(E^{(0)}_{\qty{S_i}}-H M_{\qty{S_i}})
]
$$
$$
\begin{align}
	\ev{M} &= \frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\qty{S_i}} M_{\qty{S_i}} 
	\exp \qty[
	-\beta \qty(E^{(0)}_{\qty{S_i}}-H M_{\qty{S_i}})
] = \frac1Z \frac1\beta \pdv{Z}{H}\\
\ev{M^2} &= \frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\qty{S_i}} M_{\qty{S_i}}^2
	\exp \qty[
	-\beta \qty(E^{(0)}_{\qty{S_i}}-H M_{\qty{S_i}})
] = \frac1Z \frac{1}{\beta^2} \pdv[2]{Z}{H}
\end{align}
$$

$$
\ev{M^2} - \ev{M}^2 = \frac{1}{\beta^2}
\qty[
	\frac1Z \pdv[2]{Z}{H}
	- \qty(\frac1Z \pdv{Z}{H})^2
]
$$

Meantime, with the definition of the magnetic susceptibility

$$
\begin{align}
\chi = \pdv{M}{H} &= \pdv{H} \qty(\frac1\beta \pdv{H}\ln Z) = \pdv{H} \qty(\frac{1}{N \beta} \frac{\partial Z/\partial H}{Z})\\
&= \frac{1}{N \beta} \frac{\pdv[2]{Z}{H} Z - \pdv{Z}{H}\pdv{Z}{H}}{Z^2}\\
&= \frac{1}{N\beta}
\qty[
	\frac1Z \pdv[2]{Z}{H} - \frac{1}{Z^2}
	\qty(\pdv{Z}{H})^2
]
\end{align}
$$
indicates that
$$
\chi = \frac{\beta}{N}
\qty(
	\ev{M^2} - \ev{M}^2
)
$$

>[!note] 
>In canonical ensemble, the magnetic susceptibility can also be defined as the *fluctuation* of the magnetization.

%%
- [x] Why does the fluctuation of magnetization equals to the magnetic susceptibility. (@2023-04-20)
%%

$$
\chi = \frac{\beta}{N}
\qty[
	\ev{\qty(
		\sum_{i=1}^N S_i
	)^2} - \ev{\sum_{i=1}^N S_i}^2
] = \frac{\beta}{N} \sum_{i,j=1}^N
\qty(
\ev{S_iS_j} - \ev{S_i}\ev{S_j}
)
$$

Between the energy and the specific heat, similar relation is expected.

---


# 3. Ising Models

## 3.1. 1D Ising Model

For 1D Ising model, we consider a structure demonstrated below
An Ising chain with a closed, endless structure
![[1DIsingChain.png#RIGHT|1D Ising Chain|300]]

### 3.1.1. Hamiltonian

Under this structure, we connected the $N$th and the $1$st nodes together, $S_{N+1} = S_1$. In order to that, we rewrite the hamiltonian in *symmetric form* as [^2]

$$
\ham = -J \sum_{i=1}^N S_i S_{i+1} - \frac12 H \sum_{i=1}^N (S_i + S_{i+1})
$$
### 3.1.2. Partition Function

Then its partition function
$$
\begin{align}
Z(H,T) &= \sum_{S_1 = \pm1} \cdots \sum_{S_N = \pm 1}
\exp \qty{
	\beta \sum_{i=1}^N \qty[
		J S_i S_{i+1} + \frac12 H(S_i + S_{i+1})
	]
}\\
&= \sum_{S_1 = \pm 1} \cdots \sum_{S_N = \pm 1}
\mel{S_1}{P}{S_2} \mel**{S_2}{P}{S_3} \cdots \mel**{S_{N-1}}{P}{S_N} \mel**{S_N}{P}{S_1}
\end{align}
$$
where $P$ denotes an operator, that is
$$
P = \mqty[\me^{\beta (J + H)} & \me^{-\beta J}\\
\me^{-\beta J} & \me^{\beta(J - H)}],\quad
\mel{S_i}{P}{S_{i+1}} = \exp
\qty{
\beta \qty[
		J S_i S_{i+1} + \frac12 H (S_i + S_{i+1})
	]
}
$$
In consequence, the partition function is
$$
\begin{align}
Z(H,T) &= \sum_{S_1=\pm1} \mel{S_1}{P^N}{S_1}\\
&= \mel**{1}{P^N}{1} + \mel**{-1}{P^N}{-1}\\
&= \Tr \qty(P^N)
\end{align}
$$
> [!note] Spin-Reflection Symmetry
> 可见，配分函数 $Z$ 与矩阵 $P$ 的 [[trace]] 相关联，而与具体的 [[spin]] 配置无关。进而可得到 [[#^4a58b6|Spin-Reflection Symmetry]].

[[矩阵对角化|Diagonalize]] the matrix $P$, the eigenvalues are ^9ef891
$$
\begin{align}
	\lambda_{1,2} = \me^{\beta J} \qty[
	\cosh(\beta H) \pm \sqrt{\sinh^2(\beta H) + \me^{-4 \beta J}}] \to D \equiv \mqty[\lambda_1 & 0\\ 0 & \lambda_2]
\end{align}
$$
$$
\begin{align}
	\Tr \qty(P^N) &= \Tr \qty(D^N)\\
	&= \Tr \mqty[\lambda_1^N & 0\\ 0 & \lambda_2^N]\\
	&= \lambda_1^N + \lambda_2^N
\end{align}
$$

After we assume that $\lambda_1 > \lambda_2$, in the thermodynamics limit
$$
\boxed{
Z = \lambda_1^N + \lambda_2^N = \lambda_1^N \qty[1+\qty(\frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1})^N] \to \lambda_1^N
}
$$
### 3.1.3. Thermodynamic Variables

#### 3.1.3.1. Free Energy

$$
\begin{align}
F &= -\frac{N}{\beta} \ln \lambda_1\\
&= -\frac{N}{\beta} \ln
\qty{
	\me^{\beta J} \qty[
		\cosh (\beta H)
		+ \sqrt{\sinh^2(\beta H) + \me^{-4 \beta J}}
	]
}
\end{align}
$$

#### 3.1.3.2. Magnetization $M$

$$
\begin{align}
	M &= -\pdv{F}{H} = N \frac{\sinh(\beta H)}{\sqrt{\sinh^2 (\beta H) + \me^{-4 \beta J}}}
\end{align}
$$

## 3.2. 2D Ising Model

%%
- [ ] 2D Ising Model (@2023-04-25)
%%


---

# 4. Symmetries

## 4.1. Spin-Reflection Symmetry

For the Hamiltonian of the Ising model, the operation of inverting all the spins is *equivalent* to inverting the magnetic field.
$$
-J \sum_{\ev{ij}} (-S_i) (-S_j) - H \sum_{j=1}^N (-S_j) = -J \sum_{\ev{ij}} S_i S_j - (-H) \sum_{j=1}^N S_j
$$

Meanwhile, its [[partition function]], is independent of specific spin direction, but connects with the [[Ising Model#^9ef891|matrix]] $P$. It's not matter if we substitute inverted spin, and the partition function will *stay unchanged*. ^4a58b6

Thus, the partition function $Z$ and the free energy $F/f$ are *even* functions of magnetic field $H$
$$
\begin{align}
Z(\beta, H) &= Z(\beta, -H)\\
f(\beta, H) &= f(\beta, -H)
\end{align}
$$



## 4.2. Sublattice Symmetry

# 5. Phase Transition





[^1]: Takahashi, Kazutaka, and Hidetoshi Nishimori. *相転移・臨界現象とくりこみ群*. Tōkyō-to Chiyoda-ku: Maruzen Shuppan, 29.

[^2]: Pathria, Raj K., and Paul D. Beale. _Statistical Mechanics_. Fourth edition. London San Diego Cambridge, MA Oxford: Academic Press, an imprint of Elsevier, 2022.

---END NOTE---

content: Explain Lee-Yang zeros

The Lee-Yang zeros are a set of complex numbers that are associated with the partition function of a physical system. They were first introduced by Lee and Yang in 1952 as a tool to study the phase transitions of the Ising model.

The partition function is a complex-valued function of the temperature and the external magnetic field, and it can be written as a sum over all possible configurations of the spins in the Ising model. The Lee-Yang zeros are the complex roots of the partition function in the complex temperature plane.

The Lee-Yang zeros have several interesting properties. For example, they lie on the imaginary axis in the thermodynamic limit, and their distribution can be used to determine the location and nature of phase transitions in the Ising model. In particular, the zeros cross the real axis at the critical temperature, indicating a phase transition.

The Lee-Yang zeros have also been used to study phase transitions in other physical systems, such as the Potts model and the XY model. In these cases, the zeros can be used to determine the number and nature of the phases of the system.

Overall, the Lee-Yang zeros provide a powerful tool for studying phase transitions and the critical behavior of physical systems.

content: 根据我的笔记, Fock state 是什么

根据你的笔记，Fock态是一种量子态，它是由多个单粒子态组成的。在Fock态中，每个单粒子态可以有任意多个粒子占据，也可以没有粒子占据。Fock态通常用于描述多粒子量子系统的基态或激发态，例如原子、分子和凝聚态物质等。在Fock态中，每个单粒子态的占据情况可以用一组整数$n_i$来描述，其中$n_i$表示第$i$个单粒子态中的粒子数。因此，Fock态可以写成如下形式：

$$
|n_1, n_2, n_3, \ldots \rangle
$$

其中，$n_i$可以取任意非负整数值，表示第$i$个单粒子态中的粒子数。Fock态是量子力学中非常重要的概念，它在描述多粒子量子系统的基态和激发态时具有重要的应用价值。
